Unlike existing frameworks that assume static knowledge, this study explores knowledge-driven sequence classification where different knowledge segments must be leveraged at varying timesteps, incorporating temporal relations. The authors introduce a novel benchmarking framework to rigorously evaluate the performance of various architectures. Their experimental setup compares multi-stage neuro-symbolic systems with traditional neural-only approaches. Results reveal the complexity and difficulties inherent in this new setting, indicating significant limitations of current neuro-symbolic methods. By illuminating these under-explored challenges, the findings serve as an essential reference point for future research in the field, prompting further investigation into the optimization of neuro-symbolic techniques within time-sensitive learning tasks. Overall, the study marks a significant contribution to understanding how background knowledge can be effectively integrated into artificial intelligence systems operating in dynamic environments.
arXiv:2505.05106v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: One of the goals of neuro-symbolic artificial intelligence is to exploit background knowledge to improve the performance of learning tasks. However, most of the existing frameworks focus on the simplified scenario where knowledge does not change over time and does not cover the temporal dimension. In this work we consider the much more challenging problem of knowledge-driven sequence classification where different portions of knowledge must be employed at different timesteps, and temporal relations are available. Our experimental evaluation compares multi-stage neuro-symbolic and neural-only architectures, and it is conducted on a newly-introduced benchmarking framework. Results demonstrate the challenging nature of this novel setting, and also highlight under-explored shortcomings of neuro-symbolic methods, representing a precious reference for future research.

item.title: Multi-agent Embodied AI: Advances and Future Directions
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Embodied AI, multi-agent systems, real-world applications, adaptation, collaborative problem-solving

Summary: Embodied artificial intelligence (Embodied AI) integrates AI systems with physical bodies, utilizing sensors and actuators to interact with real-world environments effectively. As techniques like deep learning, reinforcement learning, and large language models advance, the field sees applications in robotics, healthcare, transportation, and manufacturing. However, most research has focused on single-agent systems in static, closed environments. In contrast, real-world scenarios demand more complex, dynamic interactions. These environments require agents to collaborate and adapt, highlighting a need for sophisticated mechanisms for real-time learning and problem-solving. Despite a growing interest in multi-agent systems, existing research remains limited and often relies on oversimplified models. This paper addresses the lack of comprehensive surveys on multi-agent embodied AI, emphasizing the importance of understanding its complexity. It reviews current research, analyzes key contributions, and identifies challenges and future directions. The insights provided aim to guide innovation and progress in addressing the real-world challenges presented by embodied AI systems in multi-agent environments. Understanding these dynamics is crucial as the field continues to evolve rapidly.
arXiv:2505.05108v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Embodied artificial intelligence (Embodied AI) plays a pivotal role in the application of advanced technologies in the intelligent era, where AI systems are integrated with physical bodies that enable them to perceive, reason, and interact with their environments. Through the use of sensors for input and actuators for action, these systems can learn and adapt based on real-world feedback, allowing them to perform tasks effectively in dynamic and unpredictable environments. As techniques such as deep learning (DL), reinforcement learning (RL), and large language models (LLMs) mature, embodied AI has become a leading field in both academia and industry, with applications spanning robotics, healthcare, transportation, and manufacturing. However, most research has focused on single-agent systems that often assume static, closed environments, whereas real-world embodied AI must navigate far more complex scenarios. In such settings, agents must not only interact with their surroundings but also collaborate with other agents, necessitating sophisticated mechanisms for adaptation, real-time learning, and collaborative problem-solving. Despite increasing interest in multi-agent systems, existing research remains narrow in scope, often relying on simplified models that fail to capture the full complexity of dynamic, open environments for multi-agent embodied AI. Moreover, no comprehensive survey has systematically reviewed the advancements in this area. As embodied AI rapidly evolves, it is crucial to deepen our understanding of multi-agent embodied AI to address the challenges presented by real-world applications. To fill this gap and foster further development in the field, this paper reviews the current state of research, analyzes key contributions, and identifies challenges and future directions, providing insights to guide innovation and progress in this field.

item.title: Is there a half-life for the success rates of AI agents?
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI agents, task performance, failure rate, empirical model, subtasks

Summary: The article builds on the research conducted by Kwa et al. (2025) and analyzes the performance of AI agents on longer-duration tasks. It proposes a simple mathematical model that attributes task performance to a constant failure rate for every minute a human would take to complete a task. This leads to an understanding that the success rate of the agents declines exponentially with the length of the task. Each AI agent can be characterized by a specific half-life, allowing for the estimation of success rates at varying task durations. The model effectively fits the observed data, suggesting that tasks of greater length typically consist of many subtasks, where a failure in any one subtask results in the failure of the overall task. This finding raises questions about the general applicability of the model across different task categories, highlighting the need for further research to explore its broader implications. Overall, the study underscores how task complexity and failure patterns can inform our understanding of AI performance in research-engineering contexts.
arXiv:2505.05115v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Building on the recent empirical work of Kwa et al. (2025), I show that within their suite of research-engineering tasks the performance of AI agents on longer-duration tasks can be explained by an extremely simple mathematical model -- a constant rate of failing during each minute a human would take to do the task. This implies an exponentially declining success rate with the length of the task and that each agent could be characterised by its own half-life. This empirical regularity allows us to estimate the success rate for an agent at different task lengths. And the fact that this model is a good fit for the data is suggestive of the underlying causes of failure on longer tasks -- that they involve increasingly large sets of subtasks where failing any one fails the task. Whether this model applies more generally on other suites of tasks is unknown and an important subject for further work.

item.title: MARK: Memory Augmented Refinement of Knowledge
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, refined memory, knowledge gap, Memory-Augmented Refinement, personalized AI

Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are useful for specialized tasks but have difficulty keeping up with evolving domain knowledge without costly fine-tuning. Domain knowledge includes immutable facts and evolving insights shaped by real-world changes. A significant gap exists between the nuanced understanding of domain experts and the knowledge LLMs possess, which can affect information retrieval and application. To address this, the Memory-Augmented Refinement of Knowledge (MARK) framework enables LLMs to continuously learn by utilizing structured refined memory through specialized agents. These agents include the Residual Refined Memory Agent, which stores domain-specific insights; the User Question Refined Memory Agent, which captures user-provided terminology; and the LLM Response Refined Memory Agent, which extracts key elements for refinement. They work together to analyze stored memory, resolve contradictions, and enhance response accuracy, factoring in recency and relevance. MARK enhances LLMs by reducing hallucinations through a structured reference (Ground Truth Strategy), facilitating domain-specific adaptation, especially in sensitive fields like healthcare, and improving personalized AI interactions by remembering user preferences for coherent responses over time.
arXiv:2505.05177v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) assist in specialized tasks but struggle to align with evolving domain knowledge without costly fine-tuning. Domain knowledge consists of: Knowledge: Immutable facts (e.g., 'A stone is solid') and generally accepted principles (e.g., ethical standards); Refined Memory: Evolving insights shaped by business needs and real-world changes. However, a significant gap often exists between a domain expert's deep, nuanced understanding and the system's domain knowledge, which can hinder accurate information retrieval and application. Our Memory-Augmented Refinement of Knowledge (MARK) framework enables LLMs to continuously learn without retraining by leveraging structured refined memory, inspired by the Society of Mind. MARK operates through specialized agents, each serving a distinct role: Residual Refined Memory Agent: Stores and retrieves domain-specific insights to maintain context over time; User Question Refined Memory Agent: Captures user-provided facts, abbreviations, and terminology for better comprehension; LLM Response Refined Memory Agent: Extracts key elements from responses for refinement and personalization. These agents analyse stored refined memory, detect patterns, resolve contradictions, and improve response accuracy. Temporal factors like recency and frequency prioritize relevant information while discarding outdated insights. MARK enhances LLMs in multiple ways: Ground Truth Strategy: Reduces hallucinations by establishing a structured reference; Domain-Specific Adaptation: Essential for fields like healthcare, law, and manufacturing, where proprietary insights are absent from public datasets; Personalized AI Assistants: Improves virtual assistants by remembering user preferences, ensuring coherent responses over time.

item.title: Societal and technological progress as sewing an ever-growing, ever-changing, patchy, and polychrome quilt
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Artificial Intelligence, alignment, moral diversity, appropriateness framework, conflict management

Summary: The paper addresses the pressing issue of ensuring that AI systems operate ethically as they increasingly impact areas such as online moderation and policy advice. It critiques a prevalent approach known as "alignment," which assumes a unified ethical framework, arguing that it neglects moral diversity and could lead to resistance and erosion of trust in institutions. The authors identify the underlying problem as the Axiom of Rational Convergence, which posits that rational agents will eventually agree on a single ethics under ideal conditions. They suggest that this idea is both dubious and optional. To tackle the issues of moral disagreement, the paper proposes the appropriateness framework, which is built on principles from conflict theory, cultural evolution, multi-agent systems, and institutional economics. This framework accepts persistent disagreement as normal and promotes four key principles: contextual grounding, community customization, continual adaptation, and polycentric governance. The authors argue that shifting the metaphor of alignment from one of moral unification to conflict management through these principles is both necessary and urgent for the future of ethical AI.
arXiv:2505.05197v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems are increasingly placed in positions where their decisions have real consequences, e.g., moderating online spaces, conducting research, and advising on policy. Ensuring they operate in a safe and ethically acceptable fashion is thus critical. However, most solutions have been a form of one-size-fits-all "alignment". We are worried that such systems, which overlook enduring moral diversity, will spark resistance, erode trust, and destabilize our institutions. This paper traces the underlying problem to an often-unstated Axiom of Rational Convergence: the idea that under ideal conditions, rational agents will converge in the limit of conversation on a single ethics. Treating that premise as both optional and doubtful, we propose what we call the appropriateness framework: an alternative approach grounded in conflict theory, cultural evolution, multi-agent systems, and institutional economics. The appropriateness framework treats persistent disagreement as the normal case and designs for it by applying four principles: (1) contextual grounding, (2) community customization, (3) continual adaptation, and (4) polycentric governance. We argue here that adopting these design principles is a good way to shift the main alignment metaphor from moral unification to a more productive metaphor of conflict management, and that taking this step is both desirable and urgent.

item.title: ChemRxivQuest: A Curated Chemistry Question-Answer Database Extracted from ChemRxiv Preprints
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: ChemRxivQuest, QA pairs, NLP, dataset, chemistry

Summary: The article presents ChemRxivQuest, a new dataset aimed at addressing the challenges researchers face in accessing chemistry literature. It consists of 970 high-quality question-answer (QA) pairs derived from 155 ChemRxiv preprints across 17 chemistry subfields, ensuring that each QA pair is traceable to its source for contextual integrity. The dataset was created through an automated pipeline that employs optical character recognition (OCR), GPT-4o for generating QA pairs, and a fuzzy matching technique to verify answers. It focuses on various types of questions, including conceptual, mechanistic, applied, and experimental, making it valuable for retrieval-based QA systems, search engines, and the fine-tuning of large language models tailored for chemistry. The authors analyze the dataset's structure and coverage, discussing its limitations while also suggesting future directions for its expansion and the need for expert validation. ChemRxivQuest emerges as a foundational resource for advancing research, educational endeavors, and tool development in the field of chemistry-focused natural language processing.
arXiv:2505.05232v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid expansion of chemistry literature poses significant challenges for researchers seeking to efficiently access domain-specific knowledge. To support advancements in chemistry-focused natural language processing (NLP), we present ChemRxivQuest, a curated dataset of 970 high-quality question-answer (QA) pairs derived from 155 ChemRxiv preprints across 17 subfields of chemistry. Each QA pair is explicitly linked to its source text segment to ensure traceability and contextual accuracy. ChemRxivQuest was constructed using an automated pipeline that combines optical character recognition (OCR), GPT-4o-based QA generation, and a fuzzy matching technique for answer verification. The dataset emphasizes conceptual, mechanistic, applied, and experimental questions, enabling applications in retrieval-based QA systems, search engine development, and fine-tuning of domain-adapted large language models. We analyze the dataset's structure, coverage, and limitations, and outline future directions for expansion and expert validation. ChemRxivQuest provides a foundational resource for chemistry NLP research, education, and tool development.

item.title: Advancing Neural Network Verification through Hierarchical Safety Abstract Interpretation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: formal verification, deep neural networks, safety properties, abstract interpretation, adversarial inputs

Summary: Traditional formal verification methods for deep neural networks (DNNs) rely on a binary classification of safety properties, categorizing models purely as safe or unsafe. This limited approach often overlooks the gradations of safety levels, leading to overly stringent or lenient requirements. The paper introduces a new concept termed Abstract DNN-Verification, which allows for the verification of a hierarchical structure of unsafe outputs. This innovative method offers a nuanced safety analysis by employing abstract interpretation and examining output reachable sets, enabling the evaluation of multiple safety levels within the verification process. Remarkably, this approach can match or even reduce the computational demands of traditional binary verification methods. Furthermore, the formulation allows for the ranking of adversarial inputs based on their degree of safety level violation, leading to a more thorough assessment of a model's safety and robustness. The authors present a theoretical exploration linking this new formulation to existing methods that use abstract interpretation for robustness verification, conduct a complexity analysis, and provide empirical results leveraging both complex deep reinforcement learning tasks and standard DNN-Verification benchmarks.
arXiv:2505.05235v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Traditional methods for formal verification (FV) of deep neural networks (DNNs) are constrained by a binary encoding of safety properties, where a model is classified as either safe or unsafe (robust or not robust). This binary encoding fails to capture the nuanced safety levels within a model, often resulting in either overly restrictive or too permissive requirements. In this paper, we introduce a novel problem formulation called Abstract DNN-Verification, which verifies a hierarchical structure of unsafe outputs, providing a more granular analysis of the safety aspect for a given DNN. Crucially, by leveraging abstract interpretation and reasoning about output reachable sets, our approach enables assessing multiple safety levels during the FV process, requiring the same (in the worst case) or even potentially less computational effort than the traditional binary verification approach. Specifically, we demonstrate how this formulation allows rank adversarial inputs according to their abstract safety level violation, offering a more detailed evaluation of the model's safety and robustness. Our contributions include a theoretical exploration of the relationship between our novel abstract safety formulation and existing approaches that employ abstract interpretation for robustness verification, complexity analysis of the novel problem introduced, and an empirical evaluation considering both a complex deep reinforcement learning task (based on Habitat 3.0) and standard DNN-Verification benchmarks.

item.title: A Pain Assessment Framework based on multimodal data and Deep Machine Learning methods
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: pain assessment, computational methods, multimodal configurations, artificial intelligence, state-of-the-art results

Summary: This Ph.D. thesis focuses on the clinical-theoretical aspects of pain assessment while evaluating existing automated techniques. The main goal is to create advanced computational methods for automatic pain evaluation that perform well and are usable in real clinical environments. A significant aim is to investigate demographic factors influencing pain perception through a computational lens. The research intends to design and implement automatic pain assessment frameworks for both unimodal and multimodal scenarios, catering to various clinical needs. The studies included in this thesis demonstrate the success of the proposed methods, achieving state-of-the-art outcomes in the field. Furthermore, the work lays the groundwork for future explorations in artificial intelligence, particularly within the domains of foundational models and generative AI techniques.
arXiv:2505.05396v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: From the original abstract: This thesis initially aims to study the pain assessment process from a clinical-theoretical perspective while exploring and examining existing automatic approaches. Building on this foundation, the primary objective of this Ph.D. project is to develop innovative computational methods for automatic pain assessment that achieve high performance and are applicable in real clinical settings. A primary goal is to thoroughly investigate and assess significant factors, including demographic elements that impact pain perception, as recognized in pain research, through a computational standpoint. Within the limits of the available data in this research area, our goal was to design, develop, propose, and offer automatic pain assessment pipelines for unimodal and multimodal configurations that are applicable to the specific requirements of different scenarios. The studies published in this Ph.D. thesis showcased the effectiveness of the proposed methods, achieving state-of-the-art results. Additionally, they paved the way for exploring new approaches in artificial intelligence, foundation models, and generative artificial intelligence.

item.title: EcoAgent: An Efficient Edge-Cloud Collaborative Multi-Agent Framework for Mobile Automation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: EcoAgent, mobile agents, edge-cloud collaboration, task success rates, token consumption

Summary: The paper introduces EcoAgent, an innovative framework aimed at enhancing mobile automation through a collaborative system involving both edge and cloud components. EcoAgent comprises a cloud-based Planning Agent and two edge-based agents: the Execution Agent to carry out actions and the Observation Agent to verify results. A significant advantage of this system is the Observation Agent's Pre-Understanding Module, which converts screen images into concise text, thereby minimizing token usage for large language models (LLMs). This reduction is crucial given the high latency and cost typically associated with cloud-based LLMs. In the event of task failures, the Planning Agent utilizes a Reflection Module to reassess and replan based on retrieved screen history. Experiments conducted on the AndroidWorld platform demonstrate that EcoAgent effectively maintains high task success rates while notably decreasing LLM token consumption, making it both efficient and applicable for practical mobile automation scenarios. Overall, EcoAgent represents a promising solution in the field of mobile automation, balancing the strengths of cloud and edge computing while optimizing resource usage.
arXiv:2505.05440v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Cloud-based mobile agents powered by (multimodal) large language models ((M)LLMs) offer strong reasoning abilities but suffer from high latency and cost. While fine-tuned (M)SLMs enable edge deployment, they often lose general capabilities and struggle with complex tasks. To address this, we propose EcoAgent, an Edge-Cloud cOllaborative multi-agent framework for mobile automation. EcoAgent features a closed-loop collaboration among a cloud-based Planning Agent and two edge-based agents: the Execution Agent for action execution and the Observation Agent for verifying outcomes. The Observation Agent uses a Pre-Understanding Module to compress screen images into concise text, reducing token usage. In case of failure, the Planning Agent retrieves screen history and replans via a Reflection Module. Experiments on AndroidWorld show that EcoAgent maintains high task success rates while significantly reducing MLLM token consumption, enabling efficient and practical mobile automation.

item.title: Conversational Process Model Redesign
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, business process management, process model redesign, explainable changes, domain experts

Summary: The rise of large language models (LLMs) is facilitating the development of AI-augmented Business Process Management (BPM) systems that allow for conversational interactions. Most existing research concentrates on single-prompt use, overlooking the potential for continuous dialogue with users. This paper introduces the Conversational Process Model Redesign (CPD) approach, which empowers domain experts to iteratively create and redesign process models based on natural language inputs. The CPD approach involves three steps: identifying process change patterns from existing literature, rephrasing user requests to fit these patterns, and applying the necessary changes to the process model. This multi-step framework promotes explainability and reproducibility in modifications. An extensive evaluation was conducted to assess the feasibility of the CPD method and the handling of identified patterns by the LLM. Results indicated that while some patterns can be challenging for both LLMs and users to comprehend, overall, most change requests were successfully managed according to established criteria of completeness and correctness. The study highlights the necessity of user support in articulating changes effectively for improved outcomes.
arXiv:2505.05453v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the recent success of large language models (LLMs), the idea of AI-augmented Business Process Management systems is becoming more feasible. One of their essential characteristics is the ability to be conversationally actionable, allowing humans to interact with the LLM effectively to perform crucial process life cycle tasks such as process model design and redesign. However, most current research focuses on single-prompt execution and evaluation of results, rather than on continuous interaction between the user and the LLM. In this work, we aim to explore the feasibility of using LLMs to empower domain experts in the creation and redesign of process models in an iterative and effective way. The proposed conversational process model redesign (CPD) approach receives as input a process model and a redesign request by the user in natural language. Instead of just letting the LLM make changes, the LLM is employed to (a) identify process change patterns from literature, (b) re-phrase the change request to be aligned with an expected wording for the identified pattern (i.e., the meaning), and then to (c) apply the meaning of the change to the process model. This multi-step approach allows for explainable and reproducible changes. In order to ensure the feasibility of the CPD approach, and to find out how well the patterns from literature can be handled by the LLM, we performed an extensive evaluation. The results show that some patterns are hard to understand by LLMs and by users. Within the scope of the study, we demonstrated that users need support to describe the changes clearly. Overall the evaluation shows that the LLMs can handle most changes well according to a set of completeness and correctness criteria.

item.title: Toward Holistic Evaluation of Recommender Systems Powered by Generative Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: recommender systems, generative models, evaluation challenges, personalization, content safety

Summary: The paper discusses the advancements and risks associated with recommender systems powered by generative models (Gen-RecSys). It highlights the dual nature of these systems: while they enhance personalization and user engagement through dynamic content and interactive dialogues, they also pose new risks such as the creation of nonexistent items (hallucinations), the amplification of biases, and potential privacy breaches. Traditional metrics used to evaluate accuracy are inadequate as they do not address issues related to factual correctness, content safety, or alignment with user intent. The authors categorize the evaluation challenges into two main groups: (i) concerns that are aggravated by generative outputs (like bias and privacy) and (ii) new risks specific to generative models (such as contradictory explanations). To tackle these challenges, the paper proposes a comprehensive evaluation approach that emphasizes scenario-based assessments and employs multiple metrics, including relevance, factual grounding, bias detection, and compliance with policies. The aim is to establish a robust framework that assists researchers and practitioners in effectively evaluating Gen-RecSys, promoting responsible deployment, and enhancing personalization strategies.
arXiv:2504.06667v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Recommender systems powered by generative models (Gen-RecSys) extend beyond classical item ranking by producing open-ended content, which simultaneously unlocks richer user experiences and introduces new risks. On one hand, these systems can enhance personalization and appeal through dynamic explanations and multi-turn dialogues. On the other hand, they might venture into unknown territory-hallucinating nonexistent items, amplifying bias, or leaking private information. Traditional accuracy metrics cannot fully capture these challenges, as they fail to measure factual correctness, content safety, or alignment with user intent. This paper makes two main contributions. First, we categorize the evaluation challenges of Gen-RecSys into two groups: (i) existing concerns that are exacerbated by generative outputs (e.g., bias, privacy) and (ii) entirely new risks (e.g., item hallucinations, contradictory explanations). Second, we propose a holistic evaluation approach that includes scenario-based assessments and multi-metric checks-incorporating relevance, factual grounding, bias detection, and policy compliance. Our goal is to provide a guiding framework so researchers and practitioners can thoroughly assess Gen-RecSys, ensuring effective personalization and responsible deployment.

item.title: How Social is It? A Benchmark for LLMs' Capabilities in Multi-user Multi-turn Social Agent Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, social agents, benchmark, COT complexity, HSII dataset

Summary: The article addresses the need for large language models (LLMs) to function effectively in multi-user, multi-turn social agent tasks, moving beyond their role as auxiliary assistants. Currently, the measurement of LLM capabilities in these scenarios lacks systematic benchmarks. To fill this gap, the authors introduce an agent task leveling framework based on sociological principles and a new benchmark called How Social Is It (HSII) designed to assess LLM social capabilities. HSII consists of four stages: format parsing, target selection, target switching conversation, and stable conversation, aimed at evaluating communication and task completion in realistic social interactions. The dataset used for HSII, HSII-Dataset, is derived from news data through a step-by-step process. The authors also conduct an ablation study through dataset clustering and investigate the effectiveness of the chain of thought (COT) method, introducing a new metric, COT-complexity, to measure the efficiency of LLMs when using COT for specific social tasks. Various experimental results indicate that HSII is a robust benchmark for evaluating the social skills of LLMs.
arXiv:2505.04628v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Expanding the application of large language models (LLMs) to societal life, instead of primary function only as auxiliary assistants to communicate with only one person at a time, necessitates LLMs' capabilities to independently play roles in multi-user, multi-turn social agent tasks within complex social settings. However, currently the capability has not been systematically measured with available benchmarks. To address this gap, we first introduce an agent task leveling framework grounded in sociological principles. Concurrently, we propose a novel benchmark, How Social Is It (we call it HSII below), designed to assess LLM's social capabilities in comprehensive social agents tasks and benchmark representative models. HSII comprises four stages: format parsing, target selection, target switching conversation, and stable conversation, which collectively evaluate the communication and task completion capabilities of LLMs within realistic social interaction scenarios dataset, HSII-Dataset. The dataset is derived step by step from news dataset. We perform an ablation study by doing clustering to the dataset. Additionally, we investigate the impact of chain of thought (COT) method on enhancing LLMs' social performance. Since COT cost more computation, we further introduce a new statistical metric, COT-complexity, to quantify the efficiency of certain LLMs with COTs for specific social tasks and strike a better trade-off between measurement of correctness and efficiency. Various results of our experiments demonstrate that our benchmark is well-suited for evaluating social skills in LLMs.

item.title: From Dialect Gaps to Identity Maps: Tackling Variability in Speaker Verification
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Kurdish, speaker detection, dialects, machine learning, recognition performance

Summary: This work examines the complexities involved in detecting speakers of Kurdish across its multiple dialects, specifically Kurmanji, Sorani, and Hawrami. The phonetic and lexical variations among these dialects present unique challenges for speaker recognition systems. The study identifies the main difficulties faced in developing an effective speaker identification system that can accurately recognize speakers from different dialects. To enhance the accuracy and reliability of these systems, the research suggests several solutions, including the use of advanced machine learning techniques, data augmentation strategies, and the creation of comprehensive, dialect-specific corpora. The findings indicate that implementing tailored strategies for each dialect, in conjunction with cross-dialect training, significantly improves recognition performance. Overall, the work highlights the importance of addressing the distinct characteristics of each dialect to advance the field of speaker recognition for Kurdish languages effectively.
arXiv:2505.04629v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The complexity and difficulties of Kurdish speaker detection among its several dialects are investigated in this work. Because of its great phonetic and lexical differences, Kurdish with several dialects including Kurmanji, Sorani, and Hawrami offers special challenges for speaker recognition systems. The main difficulties in building a strong speaker identification system capable of precisely identifying speakers across several dialects are investigated in this work. To raise the accuracy and dependability of these systems, it also suggests solutions like sophisticated machine learning approaches, data augmentation tactics, and the building of thorough dialect-specific corpus. The results show that customized strategies for every dialect together with cross-dialect training greatly enhance recognition performance.

item.title: Adaptive Token Boundaries: Integrating Human Chunking Mechanisms into Multimodal LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal large language models, human cognition, tokenization, dynamic representation, visual-linguistic tasks

Summary: This research investigates the differences between human cognitive processes and the integration of multimodal information in computational models. It particularly focuses on the alignment between human cross-modal chunking and token representation methods in multimodal large language models (MLLMs). Empirical studies reveal that traditional static tokenization methods limit the models' ability to reflect the dynamic and context-sensitive nature of human information processing. To address this, the authors propose a new framework for dynamic cross-modal tokenization, which employs adaptive boundaries, hierarchical representations, and cognitive science-based alignment mechanisms. Quantitative results indicate that this innovative approach outperforms existing models on benchmark tasks, achieving improvements of 7.8% in Visual Question Answering and 5.3% in Complex Scene Description. Additionally, the proposed method aligns better with human-like error patterns and attention distributions. These findings enhance the understanding of the connection between human cognition and artificial intelligence, offering valuable insights for developing AI systems that better mimic human cognitive capabilities.
arXiv:2505.04637v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Recent advancements in multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in processing diverse data types, yet significant disparities persist between human cognitive processes and computational approaches to multimodal information integration. This research presents a systematic investigation into the parallels between human cross-modal chunking mechanisms and token representation methodologies in MLLMs. Through empirical studies comparing human performance patterns with model behaviors across visual-linguistic tasks, we demonstrate that conventional static tokenization schemes fundamentally constrain current models' capacity to simulate the dynamic, context-sensitive nature of human information processing. We propose a novel framework for dynamic cross-modal tokenization that incorporates adaptive boundaries, hierarchical representations, and alignment mechanisms grounded in cognitive science principles. Quantitative evaluations demonstrate that our approach yields statistically significant improvements over state-of-the-art models on benchmark tasks (+7.8% on Visual Question Answering, +5.3% on Complex Scene Description) while exhibiting more human-aligned error patterns and attention distributions. These findings contribute to the theoretical understanding of the relationship between human cognition and artificial intelligence, while providing empirical evidence for developing more cognitively plausible AI systems.

item.title: Language translation, and change of accent for speech-to-speech task using diffusion model
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: speech-to-speech translation, accent adaptation, conditional generation, diffusion models, Mel spectrograms

Summary: Speech-to-speech translation (S2ST) focuses on converting spoken input from one language to spoken output in another, traditionally emphasizing either language translation or accent adaptation. This work addresses the need for effective cross-cultural communication by proposing a unified approach that simultaneously handles both translation and accent change. The authors reformulate the S2ST task as a conditional generation problem, where the target speech is produced based on phonemes and specific features of the target speech. By employing diffusion models known for their high-fidelity generative capabilities, the authors adapt strategies from text-to-image generation. Their method conditions on source speech transcriptions and generates Mel spectrograms that embody the desired linguistic and accentual characteristics of the target language. This integrated framework allows for joint optimization of translation and accent adaptation, resulting in a more parameter-efficient and effective model compared to traditional approaches. The work highlights the potential of leveraging advanced generative techniques to improve the quality of S2ST, paving the way for better communication across diverse linguistic backgrounds.
arXiv:2505.04639v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Speech-to-speech translation (S2ST) aims to convert spoken input in one language to spoken output in another, typically focusing on either language translation or accent adaptation. However, effective cross-cultural communication requires handling both aspects simultaneously - translating content while adapting the speaker's accent to match the target language context. In this work, we propose a unified approach for simultaneous speech translation and change of accent, a task that remains underexplored in current literature. Our method reformulates the problem as a conditional generation task, where target speech is generated based on phonemes and guided by target speech features. Leveraging the power of diffusion models, known for high-fidelity generative capabilities, we adapt text-to-image diffusion strategies by conditioning on source speech transcriptions and generating Mel spectrograms representing the target speech with desired linguistic and accentual attributes. This integrated framework enables joint optimization of translation and accent adaptation, offering a more parameter-efficient and effective model compared to traditional pipelines.

item.title: Rethinking Multimodal Sentiment Analysis: A High-Accuracy, Simplified Fusion Architecture
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal sentiment analysis, emotion classification, IEMOCAP dataset, fusion-based model, computational efficiency

Summary: This article focuses on multimodal sentiment analysis, which involves understanding human emotions through the integration of language, audio, and visual signals. It highlights the trend of utilizing complex models and attention mechanisms but proposes a lightweight and effective fusion-based deep learning model for utterance-level emotion classification. The authors utilize the IEMOCAP dataset, consisting of aligned text, audio-derived numeric features, and visual descriptors, to build their model. They develop modality-specific encoders using fully connected layers along with dropout regularization to handle different types of input data. Following this, they fuse the modality-specific representations through simple concatenation, which is then processed by a dense fusion layer to explore cross-modal interactions. This streamlined architecture is designed to minimize computational overhead while maintaining strong performance. Remarkably, the model achieves a classification accuracy of 92% across six distinct emotion categories. The proposed approach shows that with effective feature engineering and modular design, simpler fusion strategies can rival or even surpass the performance of more complex models, especially in settings where computational resources are limited.
arXiv:2505.04642v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis, a pivotal task in affective computing, seeks to understand human emotions by integrating cues from language, audio, and visual signals. While many recent approaches leverage complex attention mechanisms and hierarchical architectures, we propose a lightweight, yet effective fusion-based deep learning model tailored for utterance-level emotion classification. Using the benchmark IEMOCAP dataset, which includes aligned text, audio-derived numeric features, and visual descriptors, we design a modality-specific encoder using fully connected layers followed by dropout regularization. The modality-specific representations are then fused using simple concatenation and passed through a dense fusion layer to capture cross-modal interactions. This streamlined architecture avoids computational overhead while preserving performance, achieving a classification accuracy of 92% across six emotion categories. Our approach demonstrates that with careful feature engineering and modular design, simpler fusion strategies can outperform or match more complex models, particularly in resource-constrained environments.

item.title: Multimodal Benchmarking and Recommendation of Text-to-Image Generation Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: text-to-image generation, metadata, benchmarking, evaluation framework, DeepFashion-MultiModal

Summary: This work introduces an open-source framework designed for benchmarking and evaluating text-to-image generation models. It emphasizes the role of metadata-augmented prompts in enhancing model performance. Using the DeepFashion-MultiModal dataset, the study conducts a thorough assessment of generated images through various quantitative metrics, including Weighted Score, CLIP-based similarity, LPIPS, FID, and retrieval-based measures, alongside qualitative analysis. The findings indicate that incorporating structured metadata significantly improves visual realism and semantic fidelity while also enhancing model robustness across different architectures. Although the framework does not function as a traditional recommender system, it provides task-specific guidance for model selection and prompt design based on the evaluation metrics employed. This contribution aims to support researchers in understanding and optimizing text-to-image generation processes, ultimately leading to more effective and reliable outputs. The comprehensive approach integrates both qualitative and quantitative evaluations, ensuring a well-rounded perspective on model capabilities in generating images from text descriptions enriched with metadata.
arXiv:2505.04650v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: This work presents an open-source unified benchmarking and evaluation framework for text-to-image generation models, with a particular focus on the impact of metadata augmented prompts. Leveraging the DeepFashion-MultiModal dataset, we assess generated outputs through a comprehensive set of quantitative metrics, including Weighted Score, CLIP (Contrastive Language Image Pre-training)-based similarity, LPIPS (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity), FID (Frechet Inception Distance), and retrieval-based measures, as well as qualitative analysis. Our results demonstrate that structured metadata enrichments greatly enhance visual realism, semantic fidelity, and model robustness across diverse text-to-image architectures. While not a traditional recommender system, our framework enables task-specific recommendations for model selection and prompt design based on evaluation metrics.

item.title: Advancing Conversational Diagnostic AI with Multimodal Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Language Models, diagnostic conversations, multimodal data, clinical consultations, AI evaluation

Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) show potential for facilitating diagnostic conversations, but evaluations have primarily focused on text-based interactions. In real-world care, instant messaging enables the sharing of multimodal medical artifacts between clinicians and patients. The Articulate Medical Intelligence Explorer (AMIE) enhances diagnostic performance by interpreting multimodal data during consultations. It utilizes Gemini 2.0 Flash to maintain a state-aware dialogue framework, enabling dynamic control over conversation flow based on patient states and evolving diagnoses. Follow-up questions are strategically influenced by uncertainty, resulting in an organized history-taking process reminiscent of seasoned clinicians. A randomized, blinded OSCE-style study compared AMIE's consultations to those of primary care physicians (PCPs) using 105 scenarios involving diverse artifacts such as skin photos and ECGs. The evaluation rubric focused on multimodal skills, history-taking, diagnostic accuracy, management reasoning, communication, and empathy. Findings indicate that AMIE outperformed PCPs in 7 of 9 multimodal and 29 of 32 non-multimodal evaluation axes, including diagnostic accuracy. While the results reflect significant advancements in multimodal conversational diagnostic AI, further research is needed for real-world implementation.
arXiv:2505.04653v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated great potential for conducting diagnostic conversations but evaluation has been largely limited to language-only interactions, deviating from the real-world requirements of remote care delivery. Instant messaging platforms permit clinicians and patients to upload and discuss multimodal medical artifacts seamlessly in medical consultation, but the ability of LLMs to reason over such data while preserving other attributes of competent diagnostic conversation remains unknown. Here we advance the conversational diagnosis and management performance of the Articulate Medical Intelligence Explorer (AMIE) through a new capability to gather and interpret multimodal data, and reason about this precisely during consultations. Leveraging Gemini 2.0 Flash, our system implements a state-aware dialogue framework, where conversation flow is dynamically controlled by intermediate model outputs reflecting patient states and evolving diagnoses. Follow-up questions are strategically directed by uncertainty in such patient states, leading to a more structured multimodal history-taking process that emulates experienced clinicians. We compared AMIE to primary care physicians (PCPs) in a randomized, blinded, OSCE-style study of chat-based consultations with patient actors. We constructed 105 evaluation scenarios using artifacts like smartphone skin photos, ECGs, and PDFs of clinical documents across diverse conditions and demographics. Our rubric assessed multimodal capabilities and other clinically meaningful axes like history-taking, diagnostic accuracy, management reasoning, communication, and empathy. Specialist evaluation showed AMIE to be superior to PCPs on 7/9 multimodal and 29/32 non-multimodal axes (including diagnostic accuracy). The results show clear progress in multimodal conversational diagnostic AI, but real-world translation needs further research.

item.title: Advancing 3D Medical Image Segmentation: Unleashing the Potential of Planarian Neural Networks in Artificial Intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PNN-UNet, deep neural networks, planarian neural network, image segmentation, 3D MRI

Summary: This study introduces PNN-UNet, a novel architecture designed for deep neural networks that mirrors the planarian neural network (PNN) structure, particularly in the realm of 3D medical image data. The neural structure of planarians includes two neural cords, with the cerebrum acting as a coordinator for different neurological functions. In PNN-UNet, this concept is translated into a model comprising a Deep-UNet and a Wide-UNet representing the neural cords, while a densely connected autoencoder simulates the role of the brain. This unique architectural design offers significant advantages over traditional single-network architectures like UNet and modular approaches such as Ensemble-UNet. The research findings, derived from experiments on a 3D MRI hippocampus datasetboth with and without data augmentationindicate that PNN-UNet surpasses the performance of the baseline UNet and various UNet variants in the task of image segmentation. This innovative approach suggests a new pathway for enhancing performance in medical imaging tasks through biologically-inspired neural network structures.
arXiv:2505.04664v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Our study presents PNN-UNet as a method for constructing deep neural networks that replicate the planarian neural network (PNN) structure in the context of 3D medical image data. Planarians typically have a cerebral structure comprising two neural cords, where the cerebrum acts as a coordinator, and the neural cords serve slightly different purposes within the organism's neurological system. Accordingly, PNN-UNet comprises a Deep-UNet and a Wide-UNet as the nerve cords, with a densely connected autoencoder performing the role of the brain. This distinct architecture offers advantages over both monolithic (UNet) and modular networks (Ensemble-UNet). Our outcomes on a 3D MRI hippocampus dataset, with and without data augmentation, demonstrate that PNN-UNet outperforms the baseline UNet and several other UNet variants in image segmentation.

item.title: Personalized Risks and Regulatory Strategies of Large Language Models in Digital Advertising
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, personalized advertising, BERT, user privacy, data security

Summary: This paper explores the application of large language models (LLMs) in personalized advertising while addressing user privacy and data security. It begins by detailing the principles behind LLMs, particularly focusing on the Transformer architecture and the self-attention mechanism that enables natural language processing. It introduces the BERT model, integrating it with attention mechanisms to create a personalized advertising recommendation system that also considers user risk factors. The methodology includes stages such as data collection, preprocessing, feature selection, and using BERT for semantic advertising embedding based on user profiles. The study emphasizes local model training and data encryption techniques to protect user privacy and mitigate the risk of personal data leakage. An experimental framework is designed to test the effectiveness of BERT-based advertising recommendations using real user data, demonstrating an improvement in click-through and conversion rates for ads. Moreover, the implemented privacy protection strategies are shown to effectively reduce the risks associated with user privacy breaches in the context of personalized advertising.
arXiv:2505.04665v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Although large language models have demonstrated the potential for personalized advertising recommendations in experimental environments, in actual operations, how advertising recommendation systems can be combined with measures such as user privacy protection and data security is still an area worthy of in-depth discussion. To this end, this paper studies the personalized risks and regulatory strategies of large language models in digital advertising. This study first outlines the principles of Large Language Model (LLM), especially the self-attention mechanism based on the Transformer architecture, and how to enable the model to understand and generate natural language text. Then, the BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) model and the attention mechanism are combined to construct an algorithmic model for personalized advertising recommendations and user factor risk protection. The specific steps include: data collection and preprocessing, feature selection and construction, using large language models such as BERT for advertising semantic embedding, and ad recommendations based on user portraits. Then, local model training and data encryption are used to ensure the security of user privacy and avoid the leakage of personal data. This paper designs an experiment for personalized advertising recommendation based on a large language model of BERT and verifies it with real user data. The experimental results show that BERT-based advertising push can effectively improve the click-through rate and conversion rate of advertisements. At the same time, through local model training and privacy protection mechanisms, the risk of user privacy leakage can be reduced to a certain extent.

item.title: REVEAL: Multi-turn Evaluation of Image-Input Harms for Vision LLM
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Vision Large Language Models, REVEAL Framework, multi-turn interactions, harm assessment, misinformation

Summary: Vision Large Language Models (VLLMs) combine image-processing and text understanding, enriching user interactions but also posing new safety and ethical challenges, especially in multi-modal and multi-turn conversations. Traditional evaluation methods fail to address these challenges. To meet this need, researchers developed the REVEAL (Responsible Evaluation of Vision-Enabled AI LLMs) Framework, a scalable and automated system designed for assessing harms associated with image inputs in VLLMs. The framework incorporates automated image mining, synthetic adversarial data generation, multi-turn conversational expansion via crescendo attacks, and thorough harm assessment using evaluators like GPT-4o. In their extensive evaluation of five leading VLLMs (GPT-4o, Llama-3.2, Qwen2-VL, Phi3.5V, and Pixtral), the researchers focused on three key harm categories: sexual harm, violence, and misinformation. Results demonstrated a significant increase in defect rates for multi-turn interactions compared to single-turn evaluations, revealing heightened vulnerabilities. GPT-4o showed the most balanced performance according to the Safety-Usability Index (SUI), with Pixtral closely following. Misinformation was identified as a critical concern, while Llama-3.2 and Qwen2-VL exhibited the highest defect and refusal rates, respectively.
arXiv:2505.04673v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Vision Large Language Models (VLLMs) represent a significant advancement in artificial intelligence by integrating image-processing capabilities with textual understanding, thereby enhancing user interactions and expanding application domains. However, their increased complexity introduces novel safety and ethical challenges, particularly in multi-modal and multi-turn conversations. Traditional safety evaluation frameworks, designed for text-based, single-turn interactions, are inadequate for addressing these complexities. To bridge this gap, we introduce the REVEAL (Responsible Evaluation of Vision-Enabled AI LLMs) Framework, a scalable and automated pipeline for evaluating image-input harms in VLLMs. REVEAL includes automated image mining, synthetic adversarial data generation, multi-turn conversational expansion using crescendo attack strategies, and comprehensive harm assessment through evaluators like GPT-4o. We extensively evaluated five state-of-the-art VLLMs, GPT-4o, Llama-3.2, Qwen2-VL, Phi3.5V, and Pixtral, across three important harm categories: sexual harm, violence, and misinformation. Our findings reveal that multi-turn interactions result in significantly higher defect rates compared to single-turn evaluations, highlighting deeper vulnerabilities in VLLMs. Notably, GPT-4o demonstrated the most balanced performance as measured by our Safety-Usability Index (SUI) followed closely by Pixtral. Additionally, misinformation emerged as a critical area requiring enhanced contextual defenses. Llama-3.2 exhibited the highest MT defect rate ($16.55 \%$) while Qwen2-VL showed the highest MT refusal rate ($19.1 \%$).

item.title: Proceedings The 13th International Workshop on Theorem proving components for Educational software
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: theorem proving, education, ThEdu, automated deduction, CADE

Summary: The ThEdu series aims to bridge the gap between intuitive mathematics learned in secondary school and the formal approaches required in STEM education, leveraging theorem-proving technologies for support. This volume encompasses contributions from the 13th International Workshop on Theorem Proving Components for Educational Software (ThEdu'24), which was held as a satellite event of CADE29 during IJCAR 2024 in Nancy, France. The workshop featured an invited talk by Jeremy Avigad from Carnegie Mellon University and 14 submitted presentations. An open call for papers resulted in 9 submissions, with 8 of those accepted by reviewers. The revised papers included in the volume reflect the diverse scope of ThEdu, addressing both automated deduction research and its educational applications. The volume editors express hope that the collected works will enhance the development of theorem-proving-based software and foster better collaboration between computer scientists, mathematicians, and educational stakeholders. Additionally, preparations are underway for ThEdu'25, to be held alongside the 30th International Conference on Automated Deduction (CADE-30) in Stuttgart, Germany, from July 28 to August 2, 2025.
arXiv:2505.04677v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The ThEdu series pursues the smooth transition from an intuitive way of doing mathematics at secondary school to a more formal approach to the subject in STEM education while favoring software support for this transition by exploiting the power of theorem-proving technologies. What follows is a brief description of how the present volume contributes to this enterprise. The 13th International Workshop on Theorem Proving Components for Educational Software (ThEdu'24), was a satellite event of the CADE29, part of IJCAR 2024, Nancy, France. ThEdu'24 was a vibrant workshop, with one invited talk by Jeremy Avigad (Carnegie Mellon University) and 14 submitted talks. An open call for papers was then issued and attracted 9 submissions. Eight of those submissions have been accepted by our reviewers. The resulting revised papers are collected in the present volume. The contributions in this volume are a faithful representation of the wide spectrum of ThEdu, ranging from those more focused on the automated deduction research, not losing track of the possible applications in an educational setting, to those focused on the applications, in educational settings, of automated deduction tools and methods. We, the volume editors, hope that this collection of papers will further promote the development of theorem-proving-based software and that it will allow to improve the mutual understanding between computer scientists, mathematicians, and stakeholders in education. While this volume goes to press, the next edition of the ThEdu workshop is being prepared: ThEdu'25 will be a satellite event of the 30th international Conference on Automated DEduction (CADE-30), July 28th - August 2nd, 2025, Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: Advanced Deep Learning Approaches for Automated Recognition of Cuneiform Symbols
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: cuneiform, deep learning, Akkadian, translation, archaeology

Summary: This paper introduces a fully automated methodology for identifying and interpreting cuneiform characters using advanced deep-learning algorithms. Five diverse deep-learning models were trained on an extensive dataset of cuneiform symbols, assessed based on several performance metrics, particularly accuracy and precision. Among these, two models stood out for their exceptional performance and were tested with cuneiform symbols related to the Hammurabi law, specifically Hammurabi Law 1. Each model successfully identified the relevant Akkadian meanings of the symbols and provided accurate English translations. Future research endeavors will explore ensemble and stacking techniques to enhance performance further, along with hybrid architectures aimed at improving detection accuracy and reliability. Additionally, the study examines the linguistic relationships between Akkadian, an ancient Mesopotamian language, and Arabic, highlighting their historical and cultural connections. This research exemplifies the potential of deep learning to decipher ancient scripts by integrating computational linguistics with archaeology, offering valuable insights for understanding and preserving human history.
arXiv:2505.04678v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: This paper presents a thoroughly automated method for identifying and interpreting cuneiform characters via advanced deep-learning algorithms. Five distinct deep-learning models were trained on a comprehensive dataset of cuneiform characters and evaluated according to critical performance metrics, including accuracy and precision. Two models demonstrated outstanding performance and were subsequently assessed using cuneiform symbols from the Hammurabi law acquisition, notably Hammurabi Law 1. Each model effectively recognized the relevant Akkadian meanings of the symbols and delivered precise English translations. Future work will investigate ensemble and stacking approaches to optimize performance, utilizing hybrid architectures to improve detection accuracy and reliability. This research explores the linguistic relationships between Akkadian, an ancient Mesopotamian language, and Arabic, emphasizing their historical and cultural linkages. This study demonstrates the capability of deep learning to decipher ancient scripts by merging computational linguistics with archaeology, therefore providing significant insights for the comprehension and conservation of human history.

item.title: Geometric Fault-Tolerant Neural Network Tracking Control of Unknown Systems on Matrix Lie Groups
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: geometric neural networks, matrix Lie groups, actuator faults, Lyapunov method, multi-agent systems

Summary: The article presents a tracking controller based on geometric neural networks for systems operating on matrix Lie groups while facing unknown dynamics, actuator faults, and bounded disturbances. It takes advantage of the left-invariance property of the tangent bundle of matrix Lie groups, which are identified as embedded submanifolds within the vector space $\R^{N\times N}$. The authors introduce learning rules for neural network weights that align with the Lie group's geometric structure and do not depend on explicit parameterization, effectively avoiding issues related to parameterization singularities. This facilitates a global search for optimal weights. Furthermore, the paper establishes the ultimate boundedness of all error signals, including neural network weights, a coordinate-free configuration error function, and tracking velocity errors, through Lyapunov's direct method. To demonstrate the effectiveness of this proposed method, simulation results are provided, focusing on decentralized formation control for multi-agent systems within the Special Euclidean group framework. The overall approach underscores the advantage of leveraging geometric insights to enhance the robustness and effectiveness of control systems in dynamic environments.
arXiv:2505.04725v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We present a geometric neural network-based tracking controller for systems evolving on matrix Lie groups under unknown dynamics, actuator faults, and bounded disturbances. Leveraging the left-invariance of the tangent bundle of matrix Lie groups, viewed as an embedded submanifold of the vector space $\R^{N\times N}$, we propose a set of learning rules for neural network weights that are intrinsically compatible with the Lie group structure and do not require explicit parameterization. Exploiting the geometric properties of Lie groups, this approach circumvents parameterization singularities and enables a global search for optimal weights. The ultimate boundedness of all error signals -- including the neural network weights, the coordinate-free configuration error function, and the tracking velocity error -- is established using Lyapunov's direct method. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we provide illustrative simulation results for decentralized formation control of multi-agent systems on the Special Euclidean group.

item.title: QBD-RankedDataGen: Generating Custom Ranked Datasets for Improving Query-By-Document Search Using LLM-Reranking with Reduced Human Effort
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Query-By-Document, information retrieval, domain-specific datasets, Large Language Models, BM25 model

Summary: The Query-By-Document (QBD) problem involves retrieving documents that match a specific query document, which can be critical for tasks like patent matching and academic literature reviews. Traditional retrieval methods, such as keyword search and document embeddings, can be tailored to perform better in specific domains, but creating custom datasets for these tasks can be expensive and time-consuming. This work introduces QBD-RankedDatagen, a novel process for generating custom QBD-search datasets and compares various methods in terms of cost, speed, and user-friendliness for domain experts. The methods leverage Large Language Models (LLMs) to incorporate expert input for scoring and ranking documents, while also providing explanations to facilitate human review. This approach aims to significantly reduce the amount of human effort required in dataset creation, while still capturing essential expert knowledge necessary for tuning retrieval models. The effectiveness of these methods is evaluated using QBD datasets from the Text Retrieval Conference (TREC), wherein the parameters of the widely-used BM25 model are fine-tuned using the datasets generated through their proposed methods.
arXiv:2505.04732v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The Query-By-Document (QBD) problem is an information retrieval problem where the query is a document, and the retrieved candidates are documents that match the query document, often in a domain or query specific manner. This can be crucial for tasks such as patent matching, legal or compliance case retrieval, and academic literature review. Existing retrieval methods, including keyword search and document embeddings, can be optimized with domain-specific datasets to improve QBD search performance. However, creating these domain-specific datasets is often costly and time-consuming. Our work introduces a process to generate custom QBD-search datasets and compares a set of methods to use in this problem, which we refer to as QBD-RankedDatagen. We provide a comparative analysis of our proposed methods in terms of cost, speed, and the human interface with the domain experts. The methods we compare leverage Large Language Models (LLMs) which can incorporate domain expert input to produce document scores and rankings, as well as explanations for human review. The process and methods for it that we present can significantly reduce human effort in dataset creation for custom domains while still obtaining sufficient expert knowledge for tuning retrieval models. We evaluate our methods on QBD datasets from the Text Retrieval Conference (TREC) and finetune the parameters of the BM25 model -- which is used in many industrial-strength search engines like OpenSearch -- using the generated data.

item.title: When Bad Data Leads to Good Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, toxicity, pre-training, post-training, data quality

Summary: The paper re-evaluates the concept of data quality in large language model (LLM) pretraining, examining its impact on model performance through pre- and post-training co-design. It investigates how using more toxic data during pre-training may lead to improved control in post-training, potentially reducing a model's output toxicity. A toy experiment is conducted to analyze how different data compositions influence feature representation geometry. Controlled experiments with Olmo-1B models reveal that as the proportion of toxic data increases, the toxicity representation becomes less entangled and more linear. Although training on toxic data initially leads to higher generational toxicity, this data also simplifies the detoxification process. Evaluations using Toxigen and Real Toxicity Prompts show that models trained with toxic data strike a better balance between lowering generational toxicity and maintaining overall capabilities when detoxification strategies like inference-time intervention (ITI) are applied. The findings indicate that considering post-training effects, the inclusion of lower-quality data may ultimately result in better-performing models.
arXiv:2505.04741v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: In large language model (LLM) pretraining, data quality is believed to determine model quality. In this paper, we re-examine the notion of "quality" from the perspective of pre- and post-training co-design. Specifically, we explore the possibility that pre-training on more toxic data can lead to better control in post-training, ultimately decreasing a model's output toxicity. First, we use a toy experiment to study how data composition affects the geometry of features in the representation space. Next, through controlled experiments with Olmo-1B models trained on varying ratios of clean and toxic data, we find that the concept of toxicity enjoys a less entangled linear representation as the proportion of toxic data increases. Furthermore, we show that although toxic data increases the generational toxicity of the base model, it also makes the toxicity easier to remove. Evaluations on Toxigen and Real Toxicity Prompts demonstrate that models trained on toxic data achieve a better trade-off between reducing generational toxicity and preserving general capabilities when detoxifying techniques such as inference-time intervention (ITI) are applied. Our findings suggest that, with post-training taken into account, bad data may lead to good models.

item.title: Exploring Zero-Shot App Review Classification with ChatGPT: Challenges and Potential
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: app reviews, classification, zero-shot learning, ChatGPT, user feedback

Summary: App reviews provide crucial insights into user experience, impacting app development and feature prioritization. Classifying these reviews into functional requirements (specific features) and non-functional requirements (broader quality attributes) is important for effective analysis. Traditional classification methods require large, domain-specific datasets which are difficult to obtain. This study investigates the use of zero-shot learning with ChatGPT to classify app reviews into four categories: functional requirement, non-functional requirement, both, or neither. The performance of ChatGPT was evaluated using a benchmark dataset of 1,880 manually annotated reviews from ten different apps across various domains. Results showed that ChatGPT achieved a strong F1 score of 0.842 in classifying reviews, despite facing challenges. The study also considers how review readability and length affect classification accuracy. Furthermore, a manual analysis was conducted to identify which review categories are more susceptible to misclassification. These findings highlight the potential of using advanced AI models like ChatGPT for efficient review classification, thereby assisting developers in making well-informed decisions regarding app improvements and user satisfaction.
arXiv:2505.04759v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: App reviews are a critical source of user feedback, offering valuable insights into an app's performance, features, usability, and overall user experience. Effectively analyzing these reviews is essential for guiding app development, prioritizing feature updates, and enhancing user satisfaction. Classifying reviews into functional and non-functional requirements play a pivotal role in distinguishing feedback related to specific app features (functional requirements) from feedback concerning broader quality attributes, such as performance, usability, and reliability (non-functional requirements). Both categories are integral to informed development decisions. Traditional approaches to classifying app reviews are hindered by the need for large, domain-specific datasets, which are often costly and time-consuming to curate. This study explores the potential of zero-shot learning with ChatGPT for classifying app reviews into four categories: functional requirement, non-functional requirement, both, or neither. We evaluate ChatGPT's performance on a benchmark dataset of 1,880 manually annotated reviews from ten diverse apps spanning multiple domains. Our findings demonstrate that ChatGPT achieves a robust F1 score of 0.842 in review classification, despite certain challenges and limitations. Additionally, we examine how factors such as review readability and length impact classification accuracy and conduct a manual analysis to identify review categories more prone to misclassification.

item.title: A Proposal for Evaluating the Operational Risk for ChatBots based on Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Generative AI, risk assessment, chatbot, vulnerability testing, operational risks

Summary: The rise of Generative AI (Gen AI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) has led to the development of sophisticated chatbots, but these tools also pose a range of operational risks beyond traditional cybersecurity issues. This research presents an innovative risk-assessment metric that evaluates potential threats to three key stakeholders: service providers, users, and third parties. The metric considers the technical complexity involved in inducing failures in chatbots, from simple errors to advanced prompt-injection attacks. Contextual factors, including industry specifics, user demographics, and severity of vulnerabilities are also integrated into the assessment. To validate the proposed metric, the study utilizes Garak, an open-source framework designed for LLM vulnerability testing, which is enhanced to address various threat vectors such as misinformation and social engineering. The methodology is demonstrated with chatbots using retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), illustrating how the resulting risk scores can inform both immediate risk mitigation and long-term model improvements. The findings highlight the necessity of multi-dimensional risk assessments in ensuring secure and dependable AI-driven conversational systems.
arXiv:2505.04784v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The emergence of Generative AI (Gen AI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) has enabled more advanced chatbots capable of human-like interactions. However, these conversational agents introduce a broader set of operational risks that extend beyond traditional cybersecurity considerations. In this work, we propose a novel, instrumented risk-assessment metric that simultaneously evaluates potential threats to three key stakeholders: the service-providing organization, end users, and third parties. Our approach incorporates the technical complexity required to induce erroneous behaviors in the chatbot--ranging from non-induced failures to advanced prompt-injection attacks--as well as contextual factors such as the target industry, user age range, and vulnerability severity. To validate our metric, we leverage Garak, an open-source framework for LLM vulnerability testing. We further enhance Garak to capture a variety of threat vectors (e.g., misinformation, code hallucinations, social engineering, and malicious code generation). Our methodology is demonstrated in a scenario involving chatbots that employ retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), showing how the aggregated risk scores guide both short-term mitigation and longer-term improvements in model design and deployment. The results underscore the importance of multi-dimensional risk assessments in operationalizing secure, reliable AI-driven conversational systems.

item.title: Flower Across Time and Media: Sentiment Analysis of Tang Song Poetry and Visual Correspondence
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Tang dynasty, Song dynasty, floral motifs, sentiment analysis, material culture

Summary: This study explores the cultural expressions during the Tang (618-907) and Song (960-1279) dynasties, focusing on floral motifs as both poetic and artistic elements. It highlights a gap in scholarship regarding the connection between literary emotions and visual culture. Employing BERT-based sentiment analysis, the research quantifies the emotional patterns associated with floral imagery in Tang Song poetry, specifically examining peonies and plum blossoms. The analysis reveals measurable shifts in emotional connotations between the two dynasties. To validate these findings, the study cross-references the textual emotional patterns with visual evidence from textiles, ceramics, and other artifacts of material culture.
